Regardless of flow or proxy mode, if the file is larger than the buffer, the file is not scanned.
A & B are correct for me

page 492 security guide states the below.

A + B are correct.





An antivirus profile in full scan mode buffers up to your specified file size limit. The default is 10 MB. That is 
large enough for most files, except video files. If your FortiGate model has more RAM, you may be able to 
increase this threshold.
Without a limit, very large files could exhaust the scan memory. So, this threshold balances risk and 
performance. Is this tradeoff unique to FortiGate, or to a specific model? No. Regardless of vendor or model, 
you must make a choice. This is because of the difference between scans in theory, that have no limits, and 
scans on real-world devices, that have finite RAM. In order to detect 100% of malware regardless of file size, 
a firewall would need infinitely large RAM—something that no device has in the real world.
Most viruses are very small. This table shows a typical tradeoff. You can see that with the default 10 MB 
threshold, only 0.01% of viruses pass through.
Answer is A and D
A & B is correct

questions.question_text: Which two statements about antivirus scanning mode are true? (Choose two.)

choices.A: In flow-based inspection mode, FortiGate buffers the file, but also simultaneously transmits it to the client
choices.C: In proxy-based inspection mode, files bigger than the buffer size are scanned
choices.B: In proxy-based inspection mode, antivirus scanning buffers the whole file for scanning, before sending it to the client
choices.D: In flow-based inspection mode, files bigger than the buffer size are scanned

Answer: C.
Apple FaceTime falls under (VoIP Catagory), (Excessive-Bandwidth Behavior) and (Vendor as Apple).
A. Correct, but that comes 2nd.
B. Correct, but that comes 2nd, as custom Filter Overrides the precedence of Category.
C. Correct, and that comes 1st.
D. Wrong, VoIP Category is monitored
So correct answer is (C).

Facetime belongs to VoIP category which is monitored here and therefore should be allowed, however, because of the behavior of the facetime "Excessive-Bandwidth", the custom filter Excessive-Bandwidth will block Facetime and the lookup won't continue to the second filter

Here is what fortigate shows about face time:
Category VoIP
Risk **
Popularity *****
Protocol UDP, TCP, SSL
Technology Client-Server
Behavior Excessive-Bandwidth
Vendor Apple

So answer is C

comments.content: Your answer it's wrong beacause in the question there is wrote - "Users who use Apple FaceTime video conferences are unable to set up meetings" - monitor state doesn't block the traffic

discussion.content: Its a trick question. All answers are speculation except for A. Based on the picture provided, A is the only answer we can say is true without a doubt. We can see its being monitored. The others we cant be 100% certain.

We know that Facetime is a member of Video /Audio category, Apple and Excessive bandwidth. We know that traffic is blocked. We know that custom filters take precedence over the category. So Facetime must be part of the custom blocked category, Answer is C.
Answer is C. Order start from override filter & the move to category. Here apple face use excessive BW and so it is filtered by custom filter.
i guess the answer is C
The answer must be C. There is no category called Apple Factime, so D cannot be correct
D must be correct because Facetime belongs to "Excessive-Bandwith" and Categoy video/audio is blocked
"Excessive Bandwidth" is not a category, so as D is written, D is not correct.

C: Custom Filter Overrides take precedence. Note that "Monitor does NOT block traffic at all, and because FaceTime uses high-quality video, it consumes a lot of bandwidth, therefore falls under "Excessive-Bandwidth".
I mean "Priority 1 and Priority 2" in the override order.
Added to this the first match in the override is the ID 1 rule, that blocks. Then applies the ID 2 rule "apple" to monitor.
Answer is C. Verified in a fortigate. Facetime belongs to "Excessive-Bandwith" . The override filter is set to "Block".

FaceTime is listed under "Excessive-Bandwidth" apps. 
So the answer is D.

comments.content: Look closer, its the behaviour not the vendor or category that is blocked.

choices.A: Strict RPF checks only for the existence of at least one active route back to the source using the incoming interface
